Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Active and nonlinear silicon photonics using hybrid thin-film lithium-niobate + silicon

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to overcome fundamental performance limitations in today's lightwave communications devices by using a hybrid nanophotonic waveguide cross-section, consisting of a bonded stack of silicon and of a ferroelectric oxide, e.g., lithium niobate. The approach is that modulators and nonlinear optoelectronic devices will be fabricated using the hybrid material, formed by oxide thin films being transferred onto a planarized silicon photonic chip using a low-temperature plasma-assisted bonding process which preserves diodes and transistors in the silicon chip.

The intellectual merit of this proposal is to realize, via use of this hybrid material system, optoelectronic devices that perform beyond the possibility frontier of devices fabricated using either material system alone. In the context of silicon photonics, the project will demonstrate a robust and high nonlinearity without sacrificing high index contrast. The project will also demonstrate more complex waveguide structures than possible in conventional lithium niobate structures.

The broader impact of this proposal is firstly, to benefit the information-driven infrastructure needs of modern society by enabling faster data networks without increasing energy consumption. Secondly, this GOALI collaboration between a university and a small business, both having committed interest in this area of research, involves two-way researcher visits, and technology and knowledge transfer. Results from this collaboration will be published in peer-reviewed literature, will form components of graduate student thesis research, and will provide a roadmap to future commercialization by interested parties. The project also target opportunities for interdisciplinary education and training of underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research in this project was directed towards developing a new class of electro-optic and nonlinear optical devices, based on a hybrid platform consisting of a crystalline thin film of nonlinear crystal (with minimal or no etching / patterning) bonded to a thin silicon waveguiding layer which is patterned precisely, yet cost-effectively, using a multi-project wafer (MPW) shared-resource foundry fabrication process. In this way, much more efficient electro-optic modulators and also nonlinear optical wavelength-conversion devices can be designed than can be achieved in “conventional” silicon photonics. The fundamental physical mechanisms underlying the electro-optic effect and the nonlinear effect which are available in Lithium Niobate (LN) are both not previously available in conventional silicon (Si) photonics. When device structures are appropriately designed, hybrid LN-Si devices can achieve orders-of-magnitude improvement in speed, efficiency and functionality.

The most important outcome of this research is the development of a foundry-compatible approach to the manufacturing of hybrid LN-Si photonic devices. Earlier approaches have used small, irregularly-shaped pieces of materials, and were carried out using ad-hoc methods with low yield and uncertain repeatability. Our work is distinct in several ways: We have investigated the design and experimental realization of hybrid waveguides and transitions in detail, and demonstrated that hybrid LN-Si waveguide devices can co-exist alongside traditional Si photonic devices on the same chip. We designed silicon photonic chips using the rules and procedure of a widely-accessible silicon photonic multi-project wafer (MPW) process hosted by a US-based national laboratory, and commercially-available LN on insulator wafers, and bonded reticle-sized pieces (regular, rectangular-shaped diced pieces which are a few centimeters on each side). We have shown how chips can be bonded such that they can be thermally ramped up and down repeatedly from room temperature to more than 300C, which is important for future processing of the bonded chip, if needed. We have also developed a thick electrode fabrication process which can be used for high-speed, low-loss signal transmission.

 Although the Si photonic part of the design and fabrication was quickly accomplished, a lot of time and effort over the second and third years was dedicated by a graduate student to creating a reliable and repeatable bonding process at UCSD’s “Nano3” shared-user cleanroom facility, when it became clear over the first year that we would have to re-develop certain basic fabrication steps on our own (especially, issues concerning thermal stability and handle (substrate) removal). Our publications, though not numerous, make significant additions to the state-of-the-art in hybrid LN-Si photonics, and some are co-authored with our GOALI partner and scientists from a partner national laboratory. The education and professional development of a graduate student and a post-doctoral researcher benefitted greatly from these external collaborations. We are proceeding with research in this direction on a sound footing, and the next steps of this work are being furthered through strong external collaborations and support.
